å†³æ–—åœºçš„æ™¨é›¾å°šæœªæ•£å°½ï¼Œé˜³å…‰é€è¿‡æ ‘æ¢¢åœ¨é’çŸ³æ¿ä¸Šç»£å‡ºé‡‘è‰²èŠ±çº¹ã€‚ä¼½ç½—ç“¦çš„å½±å­è¢«æ‹‰å¾—å¾ˆé•¿ï¼Œåƒä¸€æ”¯æ¨ªå§çš„å‡ ä½•å°ºã€‚å½“å­å¼¹ç©¿é€èƒ¸è†›çš„ç¬é—´ï¼Œä»–çœ‹è§æ–¹ç¨‹çš„è§£åœ¨çœ¼å‰åŒ–ä½œæ¼«å¤©ç¹æ˜Ÿï¼Œè€Œç›å¾·ç³å¨œçš„è£™æ‘†åœ¨æ™¨é£ä¸­é£˜æˆè¡€è‰²æ™šéœã€‚

å¤šå¹´åï¼Œé‚£äº›è¢«é—å¼ƒçš„æ‰‹ç¨¿åœ¨é˜æ¥¼ç§¯ç°ä¸­é‡è§å¤©æ—¥ã€‚æ•°å­¦å®¶ä»¬æƒŠæ„•åœ°å‘ç°ï¼Œä¼½ç½—ç“¦ç”¨ç”Ÿå‘½é“¸å°±çš„ç¾¤è®ºï¼Œç«Ÿæˆä¸ºç°ä»£æ•°å­¦çš„åŸºçŸ³ã€‚å½“ä»–çš„å…¬å¼è¢«åˆ»åœ¨å¢æ£®å ¡å…¬å›­çš„å¤§ç†çŸ³ä¸Šæ—¶ï¼Œæ™šéœæ­£å°†å¡çº³æ²³æŸ“æˆè¡€è‰² â€”â€” ä»¿ä½›äºŒåä¸€å²çš„å°‘å¹´ä»æœªç¦»å»ï¼Œåªæ˜¯åŒ–ä½œæ–¹ç¨‹å¼é‡Œæ°¸æ’çš„å˜é‡ï¼Œç»§ç»­åœ¨æ•°å­—çš„å®‡å®™ä¸­èˆè¹ˆã€‚

Ink and Stars: The Galois Chronicles

Prologue: Whispers in the Dawn Mist

The mist along the Seine wove a curtain over late spring. Twenty-one-year-old Galois squatted on the cobblestones, his rain-stained papers glowing like moon-kissed blood. His fingers traced the still-wet ink â€” equations of group theory, his lifeâ€™s essence poured out to crack the quintic equationâ€™s final riddle.

â€œÃ‰variste!â€ A church bellâ€™s chime startled a flock of egrets into flight. Galoisâ€™s pupils shrank to pinpricks as memories surfaced through the mist: four years prior, in his youth at the LycÃ©e Louis-le-Grand, his math teacher had trembled as he touched the young manâ€™s paper, his cry carrying an ominous foreboding.

The rain turned scalding. Galois envisioned Cauchyâ€™s white hair floating in the Academyâ€™s hall, those turbid eyes crumpling his unfinished paper; prison windows rusted blood-red, bread crumbs molding as he traced permutation groups with them; and the schoolmistressâ€™s daughter whoâ€™d dallied with him in the library, now approaching from the mist with blood-stained lilies.

As the duelâ€™s horn pierced the clouds, Galois folded his mud-spattered manuscript into a paper boat. It drifted down the Seine past the old guillotine site. With the first dawn light splitting Parisâ€™s dome, the youthâ€™s warmth cooled in the bullet hole in his chest, his final prophecy on the manuscriptâ€™s back blurring in the rain: â€œThe groupâ€™s dance will outlast eternity, and the fifth root can never be measured with a ruler and compass.â€

Chapter 1: The Birth of a Prodigy

The morning mist of Ã‰pinal had not yet lifted when Galoisâ€™s quill was already etching sharp lines on parchment. At fourteen, he stood on a tall stool, toes barely touching, reaching for Euclidâ€™s Elements on the highest shelf of his fatherâ€™s study. Chestnut blossoms fell on his head, but the young man was oblivious, his fingers already turning Euclidâ€™s propositions into sand. The ancient convent bell tower glowed lead-grey in the dawn light, mirroring the equations spinning in his pupils.

When he first stepped into the amphitheater of the Ã‰cole Polytechnique, mud splattered on his breeches from his morning run. He clutched his crumpled acceptance letter like a holy relic. On the podium, Cauchyâ€™s white hair floated in the candlelight, the triangle ruler clinking crisply: â€œThe quintic equationâ€™s radical solution will upend the foundations of mathematics.â€ Galoisâ€™s pen froze, ink blooming into a black poppy on the scratch paper.

Chapter 2: The Birth of Group Theory

In the midnight library, the faint candlelight cast the youthâ€™s silhouette on parchment. Galoisâ€™s quill devoured the paper like a ravenous locust. The permutation groups deemed â€œabsurdâ€ in Cauchyâ€™s papers now flowed with spiritual rhythm from his pen. As the inkwell emptied, he continued writing with his own blood, until dark red crystals formed on his palms.

â€œMathematicsâ€™ essence lies not in numbers, but in their dance,â€ he whispered to a spider on the window lattice, unaware of the headmistress approaching from the libraryâ€™s depths. Mademoiselleâ€™s skirt swept up dust as she tucked a withered iris into the young manâ€™s collar, her fingertips touching his feverish forehead: â€œYour mind burns hotter than Parisâ€™s July air.â€

When Galois handed his blood-stained paper to the French Academy of Sciences, Poissonâ€™s white gloves nearly turned red. Cauchy snickered behind a column, shoving the yellowed pages into the fireplace: â€œA childâ€™s fantasy, no match for Lagrangeâ€™s symphony.â€ As flames consumed the ink, the youthâ€™s pupils flashed with the guillotineâ€™så¯’å…‰.

Chapter 3: Revolution and Prison

The July Revolutionâ€™s smoke had not yet cleared when Galois draped the tricolor over his shoulders. He swung his fatherâ€™s sword in the street barricades, the blade and gunpowder weaving a fatal waltz. As rebelsâ€™ bodies were swallowed by the Seine, he pressed his fatherâ€™s military pistol to his temple â€” only to have Mademoiselleâ€™sçº¤æŒ‡ block it: â€œDying for mathematics is worthier than dying for freedom.â€

Prison windows gleamed with blue rust under the moon. Galois carved permutation group formulas on the stone walls with a rusty spoon, molding moldyé¢åŒ…å±‘ into group structures. One night, he heard Mademoiselle humming â€œLa Marseillaiseâ€ at the corridorâ€™s end, the melody mingling with the rhythm of dragging iron chains.

Chapter 4: The Fated Duel

In April, Paris was awash withä¸é¦™èŠ± carrying a bloody scent. Galois wrote his final letter in the attic, ink and blood intertwining into a poignant pattern on the paper. He folded the manuscript into a paper airplane, letting it soar past the old guillotine site and plummet into the Seineâ€™s silt. Mademoiselleâ€™s skirt fluttered at the street corner as she pinned a blood-stained lily to his buttonhole: â€œRemember, mathematics outlasts love.â€

The dawn mist had not yet lifted at the duel ground. Sunlight filtered through the trees, embroidering golden patterns on the cobblestones. Galoisâ€™s shadow stretched long, like a prostrate geometric ruler. As the bullet pierced his chest, he saw the equationâ€™s solution burst into a sky of stars, while Mademoiselleâ€™s skirt fluttered into a blood-red evening glow in the morning breeze.

Epilogue: The Eternal Group Theory

The Paris Medical Schoolâ€™s morgue reeked of pine and death. Galoisâ€™s body was hastily wrapped in a shroud, his identity proven only by the blood-stained equation manuscript on his chest. When his brother took the manuscript, he found on the back: â€œMy thoughts will outlast the stars.â€

Years later, those abandoned manuscripts resurfaced from attic dust. Mathematicians were shocked to find Galoisâ€™s group theory, forged in his lifeâ€™s final moments, had become modern mathematicsâ€™ bedrock. As his formulas were carved into Luxembourg Gardenâ€™s marble, the evening glow dyed the Seine blood-red â€” as if the twenty-one-year-old youth had never left, but transformed into an eternal variable in the equation, continuing to dance in the universe of numbers.

entry.content:

ä¸“åˆ©çš„å‘æ˜äººæ˜¯æ¥è‡ª3æ‰€å­¦æ ¡çš„è€å¸ˆï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ä¸»è¦çš„è´Ÿè´£äººæ˜¯æ¥è‡ªäºæ±•å¤´å¤§å­¦çš„ä¸€ä½æ•™æˆã€‚ä¸“åˆ©ä¸­æåˆ°çš„æœç´¢åŠæ³•æ˜¯åŸºäºä¸€ä¸ªå«åšâ€œRSAå› æ•°å¯†åŒ–çš„é›†åˆä½“æœç´¢â€çš„ç®—æ³•ï¼Œå…¶æ•°å­¦åŸºç¡€æ¥æºäºè¿™ä½ç‹æ•™æˆåœ¨rsaå› å­æœç´¢ä¸­çš„ç ”ç©¶ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä»–å‘æ˜äº†å¾ˆå¤šæ•°å­¦å·¥å…·æ¥è¾¾åˆ°ä»–çš„ç›®çš„ã€‚

æˆ‘å¯¹è¿™ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®æ„Ÿå…´è¶£çš„ç‚¹åœ¨äºï¼Œå®ƒæ¶‰åŠåˆ°äº†æ•°å­¦å’Œè®¡ç®—æœºç§‘å­¦çš„äº¤å‰é¢†åŸŸï¼Œå½“ç„¶è¿˜æœ‰å¯†ç å­¦çš„éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚æœ€å¤§çš„å…´è¶£åœ¨äºï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸æœ‰æŒ‘æˆ˜æ€§çš„é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œéœ€è¦æˆ‘ç†Ÿç»ƒæŒæ¡pythonç¼–ç¨‹ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å­¦ä¼šä¸æ–­åœ°ä¼˜åŒ–ä»£ç ï¼Œä»¥è¾¾åˆ°æ›´å¥½çš„æ•ˆæœã€‚

ç›®å‰ç¨‹åºçš„ç¼–å†™ä»¥åŠä¼˜åŒ–å·²ç»è¾¾åˆ°ç¬¬ä¸‰ä»£ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œåœ¨ç­‰å¾…ç‹æ•™æˆä»–ä»¬ä¼˜åŒ–ç®—æ³•ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿å¯¹åŸæ¥çš„ç¨‹åºè¿›è¡Œæ”¹è¿›ã€‚

Iâ€™d like to record a project I received two weeks ago, which is related to RSA factorization.

The project involves a patent, whose specific content wonâ€™t be shown here.

The main task of the project is to use the search method mentioned in the patent to find a factor of a given RSA public key.

The patent is invented by teachers from three schools, with the main person in charge being a professor from Shantou University. The search method mentioned in the patent is based on an algorithm called â€œRSA factor - dense set searchâ€, whose mathematical foundation comes from Professor Wangâ€™s research on RSA factor search. He also invented many mathematical tools to achieve his goal.

What interests me about this project is that it involves the intersection of mathematics and computer science, as well as cryptography. The biggest interest lies in its challenging nature, which requires me to be proficient in Python programming and constantly optimize the code for better results.

Currently, the program writing and optimization have reached the third - generation version, and we are waiting for Professor Wang and his team to optimize the algorithm to improve the original program.

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œç°åœ¨æ—¢æ˜¯æ–°æ‰‹åˆæ˜¯è€æ‰‹çš„æˆ‘ï¼Œæœ‰å¾ˆå¤§çš„å­¦ä¹ ç©ºé—´å’Œæ½œåŠ›ï¼ŒåŠ æ²¹å§ï¼ï¼

As I delve deeper into computer science, boredom has begun to permeate my learning experience.

To combat this, Iâ€™ve decided to create a blog to document my computer - learning journey.

I started learning about computers in high school, but I didnâ€™t study them in depth. After grasping some basic principles and acquiring certain programming skills, I failed to continue my in - depth learning.

Therefore, Iâ€™m now both a novice and an experienced learner with vast room for growth and great potential. Letâ€™s go!!
